awd_titl_txt: Atomistic Mechanisms of Surface- and Interface-Mediated Creep in  Small-sized Metals
awd_abstract_narration:
Irreversible, plastic deformation in polycrystalline metals normally arises from the movement of line defects, also known as dislocations. However, in materials composed of nanoscale agglomerations of crystals, i.e., nanograins, the significant amount of crystal interfaces and free surfaces could dramatically facilitate mass (atoms) transport, thereby leading to fundamentally new atomistic deformation mechanisms and distinctive mechanical properties compared to those of their large grain counterparts. Such surface or interface-mediated diffusive plasticity (creep) has been found to play a significant role in mechanical behaviour of nanomaterials even at room temperature. This project will investigate the atomistic mechanisms governing the interface and surface controlled diffusive plasticity in nanostructured metals through in-situ high-resolution microscopy. The understanding achieved through this research will have direct impact on the development of nanoscale metals and alloys with high strength and ductility, facilitating development of advanced nanomechanical devices with superior reliability. The results from this research will advance experimental mechanics at the nanoscale, and the knowledge gained will advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare by benefiting the materials and manufacturing industries. The project will also embark on an extensive plan of undergraduate and graduate curriculum development, training of underrepresented undergraduate students in advanced engineering sciences through summer internships, and outreach to elementary school students in collaboration with the local science museum.

The objective of this research is to investigate the atomistic mechanisms governing grain boundary and surface diffusive plasticity in nanostructured metallic systems through in-situ observation under high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM). Specifically, the research will be divided into two parts: firstly, the interplay/competition between dislocation plasticity and diffusional creep will be atomically resolved, with an emphasis on the coupled diffusive-displacive processes at nanocrystal surfaces and the size dependent impact of surface diffusion on the strength and ductility of nanocrystals; secondly, atomic scale grain-boundary mass transport will be investigated in nano-size metals consisting of low-angle grain boundaries during uniaxial stressing, and a quantitative model will be developed to understand the contribution of such grain-boundary-mediated diffusive process to the overall plasticity. Understanding diffusional plastic deformation process of nanostructured metallic materials will have direct impact on the development of nanoscale metals and alloys with high strength and ductility to be used for advanced MEMS/NEMS with superior reliability for elevated temperature applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Metal nanomaterials exhibit superior properties and hence have found promising applications in nanoelectromechanical systems, wearable devices, and stretchable and flexible electronics. It is desirable for metal nanomaterials to have high reliability to resist mechanical degradation and failure during the operation of these nanoscale-metal-based devices. However, it has been observed that small-sized metals show inferior (i.e., softening) mechanical properties when their characteristic size decreases to a few nanometers, possibly due to surface effects. This award supports research to acquire fundamental knowledge about the atomistic mechanisms governing the interface and surface controlled diffusive plasticity in nanostructured metals through in situ observation under high-resolution transmission electron microscope. The mechanical strength of large sized metal nanocrystals is governed by the surface dislocation nucleation due to the lack of effective dislocation sources inside the material. Below a critical size, the deformation of metal nanocrystals would switch from displacive to diffusive plasticity. This study aims to elaborate on the effect of diffusive activities on the strength and fracture of metal nanomaterials. The results attained in this research particularly enable rational design of high-fidelity nanostructured metals for nanoelectromechanical systems in the future, and hence benefit the U.S. economy and society. 

Intellectual Merit: In this project, the in situ high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and atomistic molecular dynamics (MD) simulations have been applied to obtain fundamental knowledge of surface diffusion induced abnormal softening in nanoscale Ag and Pt crystals and surface diffusion induced unusual compression fracture in Ag nanocrystals. Specifically, the notable results from this research are that: (1) surface-mediated mass transport was directly observed in Ag crystals with size below 10 nm; (2) the yield strength-size relationship was found to change from ‘smaller is stronger’ to ‘smaller is weaker’ with decreasing size of Ag crystals, whereas nanoscale Pt crystals showed traditional “Hall-Petch-like” behavior; (3) the surface-diffusion-assisted dislocation nucleation process was identified to be responsible for the inverse Hall-Petch-like effect observed in nanoscale Ag crystals; (4) in situ HRTEM compression experiments revealed that preexisting dislocation and crystal slip could serve as stimuli to activate surface atom diffusion, which leads to abnormal thinning observed in Ag nanocrystals during compression, and (5) when the size of the Ag nanocrystal was reduced to 2.65 nm, surface diffusional events was observed to lead to the tensile-fracture-like failure in the Ag nanocrystal under compression.

Broader Impacts: The project produces and disseminates new knowledge of mechanical behavior and properties of metal nanomaterials under loading relevant to their application in nanoelectromechanical systems, and thus has an impact on a broad range of fields including renewable energy, gas sensors, biomedical diagnostics, nano-electronics, aerospace and defense, which demand advanced nanomaterials with enhanced electrical and mechanical properties. The HRTEM and computation tools developed in this project have been distributed in academic community to study surface friction in nano-contacts, deformation mechanism in high entropy alloys, and temperature-dependent mechanical behavior of metallic nanomaterials. Eight research articles have been published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, and multiple technical presentations have been delivered at international conferences. One graduate student has completed a PhD thesis based on the supported research. The research results have been added as teaching materials of graduate and undergraduate courses. Through the entire life of the award, two PhD graduate students and six undergraduate students receive research training in experimental and computational materials science. Moreover, the research results have been incorporated into curriculum enhancement, student training, industrial collaboration, and an educational outreach program.
